item.title: News Analysis: Fears That Trump’s Visa Ban Betrays Friends and Bolsters Enemies
item.media:description: Syrian refugees arriving in Detroit in 2015. The Muslim world is watching closely as the Trump administration clamps down on immigration.
item.media:credit: Salwan Georges for The New York Times
item.description: Officials, analysts and citizens across Muslim-majority countries said the order was a sign that President Trump sees Islam itself as the problem.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: In Iran, Shock and Bewilderment Over Trump Visa Crackdown
item.media:description: A customs checkpoint for foreign travelers arriving at Miami International Airport.
item.media:credit: Joe Raedle/Getty Images
item.description: The new administration’s freeze on visas for a targeted group of countries could provide an early test of its relationship with Tehran.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK and JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Trump Cites Israel’s ‘Wall’ as Model. The Analogy Is Iffy.
item.media:description: The West Bank barrier in East Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: Yes, Israel did build a West Bank barrier. But it was to deter terrorists. It was never intended to stop all Palestinians from crossing into Israel.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Trump and Mexican President Speak by Phone Amid Dispute Over Wall
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico with Donald J. Trump in August, when Mr. Trump visited the country during the presidential campaign.
item.media:credit: Henry Romero/Reuters
item.description: The two spoke for about an hour, and both presidents made an effort to say that the call had been productive. However, they stood their ground on their positions.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: As Migrants Strain Border Towns, Pressure Builds on Mexico to Act
item.media:description: Haitian migrants during an evening prayer at Iglesia Central del Nazareno, a church sheltering Haitian women and children in Tijuana, Mexico.
item.media:credit: Meghan Dhaliwal for The New York Times
item.description: With shelters in Tijuana already teeming with Haitians, some advocates fear President Trump’s plan could spur a far bigger crisis that Mexico may not be able to handle.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Clinics for World’s Vulnerable Brace for Trump’s Anti-Abortion Cuts
item.media:description: A woman suffering from complications caused by an unsafe abortion at a hospital in Zongo, the Democratic Republic of Congo, in 2015. The so-called Mexico City policy prohibits organizations abroad from using American aid to discuss abortion as a method of family planning.
item.media:credit: Federico Scoppa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Health workers say President Trump’s ban on abortion counseling will hurt even those health services that do not involve abortions.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY, NORIMITSU ONISHI and SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Shabab Militants Attack Kenyan Military Base in Somalia
item.description: Representatives of the Shabab militant group and of the Kenyan Defense Ministry each claimed that they had inflicted heavy losses on the other side.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN MOHAMED

item.title: As Climate Change Accelerates, Floating Cities Look Like Less of a Pipe Dream
item.media:description: A rendering of the artificial floating island project in French Polynesia. The project is being put forward by a California nonprofit, the Seasteading Institute, which has raised about $2.5 million from more than 1,000 interested donors.
item.media:credit: Seasteading Institute
item.description: A costly plan to build floating islands shows how climate change is pushing the search for innovative solutions, but some critics ask who will ultimately benefit.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Wheels: China’s Answer to Tesla Is Hopeful Entrant to Global Car Market
item.media:description: Lu Qun, chairman of Qiantu Motor, in Beijing in December.
item.media:credit: Patrick Wack for The New York Times
item.description: Electric vehicles offer a new chance to Chinese car-making efforts that have floundered in the past. But lavish state aid could be as much bane as boon.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHUMAN

item.title: Duterte’s Free Birth-Control Order Is Latest Skirmish With Catholic Church
item.media:description: Lizel Torreras, 35, with her four children in their home in Happyland. When Ms. Torreras became pregnant with her third child, she mixed a home remedy to induce abortion but could not bring herself to drink the potion.
item.media:credit: Dondi Tawatao for The New York Times
item.description: The Philippine president’s demand gives clear guidance to local officials, after challenges by the church and others kept a 2012 law from taking full effect.
item.dc:creator: AURORA ALMENDRAL

item.title: Donald Trump and Theresa May: An Odd Couple
item.media:description: With Britain planning to leave the European Union, Prime Minister Theresa May will try to show Britons they have friends beyond Europe.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Facundo Arrizabalaga
item.description: Britain’s prime minister will meet with the president on Friday. With “Brexit” looming, she needs to show Britons that they have friends beyond Europe.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Russian Charged With Treason Worked in Office Linked to Election Hacking
item.description: The appearance of news on the arrests in four prominent publications suggested that the Kremlin may be prepared to reveal more about the matter.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: What in the World: Polish City to Give Tom Hanks the Car That Put It on the Auto Map
item.media:description: A gathering of Fiat 126p enthusiasts in Krakow, Poland. “The Maluch was the beginning of an automotive revolution in Poland,” said Jacek Krywult, the mayor of Bielsko-Biala, Poland, where the car was made.
item.media:credit: Artur Widak/NurPhoto, via Getty Images
item.description: The Maluch, built in Bielsko-Biala from the early 1970s to 2000, has developed a following that apparently includes at least one prominent fan.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: Canada Today: Trump Is a Blessing and a Curse for Trudeau
item.media:description: Chick Webster at home in Mattawa, Ontario, this month. He played for the Rangers in the 1949-50 season and is the oldest living former NHL player.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau faces a balancing act over the resurrected Keystone XL pipeline, and plays down the effects of possible Nafta changes for Canada.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: France Bans Free Soda Refills in Attack on Obesity
item.media:description: A soft drink bottling operation in Clamart, France, near Paris.
item.media:credit: Lionel Bonaventure/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The regulation is the latest attempt to tackle what the government called a relentless rise in the national obesity rate.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO de FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Trump Meets Theresa May of Britain as He Weighs Lifting Russia Sanctions
item.description: As he hosts his first foreign leader since taking office, President Trump is contemplating lifting sanctions against Russia despite European objections.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER

item.title: Nikki Haley Puts U.N. on Notice: U.S. Is ‘Taking Names’
item.description: President Trump’s new ambassador to the United Nations said the United States would respond accordingly to those who “don’t have our back.”
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Gary Lineker, Soccer Hero, Dips a Toe Into Post-Brexit British Politics
item.media:description: Gary Lineker says he understands the anger in Britain. “But all of a sudden we’re blaming all the ills of the country on refugees and foreigners. It’s just wrong.”
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Gary Lineker, the popular host of the BBC’s “Match of the Day,” has emerged as a leading critic of the exit from the European Union and of anti-immigrant views.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: Sinosphere: At Hong Kong New Year Fair, Defiance Gives Way to Resignation
item.media:description: Joshua Wong, a leader of the pro-democracy Umbrella Movement and a co-founder of the Demosisto party, spoke from the party’s stall at the Lunar New Year fair in Victoria Park in Hong Kong on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Along with fish balls and flowers, vendors in Victoria Park sold a game with a predetermined set of outcomes, a nod to the Beijing-directed selection of the city’s leader.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG

item.title: Sinosphere: Surviving Chinese New Year With the Family: A Musical How-To
item.description: A song, spreading fast online, offers a bit of relief for those dashing home to celebrate the Lunar New Year only to face relentless questions about their lives.
item.dc:creator: DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: In a Corner, President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico Punches Back
item.media:description: President Enrique Peña Nieto of Mexico this week. His cautious approach to President Trump had caused an outcry in Mexico.
item.media:credit: Ronaldo Schemidt/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The cancellation of his trip to the United States ended months of diplomacy for a leader caught between his people and an unpredictable, and at times hostile, American president.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Stephen P. Cohen, Secret Broker of Mideast Peace Talks, Dies at 71
item.media:description: Stephen P. Cohen in 1984. One Israeli politician described him as “the lone guerrilla warrior of peace.”
item.media:credit: E. F. Sher
item.description: Mr. Cohen arranged the first direct and informal talks between the Israeli government and Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader.
item.dc:creator: SAM ROBERTS

item.title: Bana al-Abed Writes Trump: ‘Please Save the Children and People of Syria’
item.description: The girl, 7, and her mother, Fatemah, posted an open letter to President Trump on Bana’s Twitter account, sharing the message with the hundreds of thousands of users who follow the account.
item.dc:creator: MEGAN SPECIA

item.title: Canada Beckons International Students With a Path to Citizenship
item.media:description: Eun Young, a student from South Korea, at the College of the North Atlantic in St. John’s, Newfoundland, in November.
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.description: Universities are welcoming students from abroad as part of a government strategy to offset the country’s aging population and slowing birthrate.
item.dc:creator: CRAIG S. SMITH

item.title: Tax Plan Sows Confusion as Tensions With Mexico Soar
item.media:description: President Trump in his office aboard Air Force One on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.description: President Trump’s plan for a wall on the border with Mexico erupted into a diplomatic standoff, as he appeared to embrace a proposal to tax all imported goods.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR, BINYAMIN APPELBAUM and ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: ‘This Feels Like Being Born Again:’ Gambians Hope for Change and Long for Home
item.media:description: Gambians in Banjul, the capital, on Saturday hearing about the imminent departure of Yahya Jammeh, who had refused to step down as president after losing an election.
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: As the new president takes power, we asked readers from Gambia about their hopes and fears for their homeland, and, for those abroad, whether they might return.
item.dc:creator: LILLIE DREMEAUX
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: His Predecessor Gone, Gambia’s New President Finally Comes Home
item.description: The president, Adama Barrow, had fled to neighboring Senegal more than a week earlier after Yahya Jammeh, his defeated predecessor, refused to cede power.
item.dc:creator: JAIME YAYA BARRY and DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Ordered to Seek Approval on ‘Brexit,’ Theresa May Does So. Tersely.
item.description: At 132 words — one of the shorter bills in British history — the bill was seen as an effort to prevent amendments that could slow its passage.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: The Interpreter: British Alignment With Trump Threatens European Order
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain arriving at Philadelphia International Airport on Thursday for her two-day visit to the United States. She will be the first world leader to meet with President Trump.
item.media:credit: Christopher Furlong/Getty Images
item.description: Britain has much to lose whichever way it turns, but it seems more concerned with its departure from the European Union than other global events.
item.dc:creator: MAX FISHER

item.title: ‘Give Us Our Children Back’: Hunger Strikers in Sri Lanka Demand Answers
item.description: In pushing officials to investigate the disappearance of thousands after a civil war ended in 2009, hunger strikers won a meeting with the country’s defense minister.
item.dc:creator: DHARISHA BASTIANS and GEETA ANAND

item.title: Mexico’s President Cancels Meeting With Trump Over Wall
item.description: The move by the Mexican leader, Enrique Peña Nieto, brings to a head the simmering tensions that have been building for months between the two nations.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED

item.title: Beirut Journal: On Lebanon’s Once-Sparkling Shores, a Garbage Dump Grows
item.media:description: A beach flooded with garbage on the outskirts of Beirut. The garbage problem has long been a symbol of a failure of Lebanese politics, one that activists say has its roots in the time shortly after the country’s civil war, which ended in 1990.
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.description: A landfill that is attracting birds that endanger aviation is a symbol of dysfunction to many in Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO and HWAIDA SAAD

item.title: Greece’s Top Court Rejects Extradition of Turkish Officers
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled that they would face “the curtailment of their fundamental human rights” if they were sent back to Turkey.
item.dc:creator: NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Eike Batista, Once Brazil’s Richest Man, Is Sought in Corruption Inquiry
item.media:description: Eike Batista, second from left, during a court hearing in Rio de Janeiro in 2014.
item.media:credit: Felipe Dana/Associated Press
item.description: The police are seeking the arrest of Mr. Batista, an oil and mining magnate, in connection with bribes paid to the former governor of Rio de Janeiro.
item.dc:creator: DOM PHILLIPS and SIMON ROMERO

item.title: South Korea Can Keep Buddha Statue Stolen From Japan, Court Says
item.media:description: Sekko Tanaka, a Buddhist monk on the Japanese island of Tsushima, in 2013, holding a photograph of a Buddha statue that was stolen the year before.
item.media:credit: Ko Sasaki for The New York Times
item.description: The ruling found that the 20-inch bronze statue had been taken from Korea centuries ago by Japanese pirates. Tokyo called the decision “regrettable.”
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Chinese New Year: Inside the World’s Largest Trek
item.media:description: Passengers at the Beijing West Railway Station. Hundreds of millions of Chinese are traveling to their hometowns for the Lunar New Year, the country’s most important holiday.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrié for The New York Times
item.description: Tens of millions are traveling from industrial regions to their hometowns to celebrate. The holiday rush is not a tranquil experience, but it has become more orderly.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY and ADAM WU

item.title: Q. and A.: How Trump’s Revival of an Abortion Ban Will Affect Women in Kenya
item.media:description: A group gathered for counseling on family planning options in western Kenya.
item.description: A family planning fellow discusses what President Trump’s ban on aid to groups who offer abortion counseling could mean for women in western Kenya.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Egypt’s Rickety Dictatorship
item.media:credit: Mitch Blunt
item.description: Six years after the start of the Egyptian revolution, President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s regime is more vulnerable than it appears.
item.dc:creator: JACK SHENKER

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Closing of Trump’s America
item.media:description: An anti-Trump protester in New York in 2015 wearing a button that reads, “Keep our Muslim neighbors SAFE” and holding a pocket copy of the U.S. Constitution.
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.description: A rough translation of “America First” is Muslims last.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Radical Right’s United Front
item.media:description: From left: Geert Wilders of the Dutch Party for Freedom; Marcus Pretzell of the Alternative for Germany party; Marine Le Pen of France’s National Front party; and Frauke Petry of the Alternative for Germany party in Koblenz, Germany, last week.
item.media:credit: Michael Probst/Associated Press
item.description: Europe’s far-right political parties are putting forth an image of unity and strength. It’s just a facade.
item.dc:creator: CAS MUDDE
